This little application is greatly indebted to the free/libre software and data contributed by the Perseus project.
 I wrote this app to satisfy a personal need, but I hope that verba-android can be of use to others.
 This is beta-quality software; please report issues and feature requests here: 
 https://github.com/grantham/verba-android/issues

 Hacking is strongly encouraged:
 Source is available from https://github.com/grantham/verba-android. Hack away!

Hack away! Source is available from https://github.com/grantham/verba-android 
 Planned features for later releases:
 * Keep a list of words looked up five or more times to be exported as flash cards
 * Reduce storage requirements while still providing off-line use
 * Provide a service for other applications to use for part-of-speech tagging and general word lookup
 * Other ideas suggested by users and hackers.

Verba-Android is released under the GPL v3 license and is based on the database produced by the Verba-Console project (see http://www.magnopere.org/index.html#verba-console)
 
 The underlying data in this database comes from two sources:
 
 1. An Elementary Latin Dictionary (1895) by Charlton T. Lewis (see http://www.archive.org/details/anelementarylat01lewigoog). This work is in the public domain, but was encoded into TEI by the Tufts University Perseus Project (http://www.perseus.tufts.edu) and the TEI-encoded XML file is released under the Creative Commons ShareAlike 3.0 License (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/us/). I understand the copyright claim can only pertain to the XML encoding the project provided and cannot extend to the underlying work which is already in the public domain.
 
 2. A Latin morphology file produced by the Perseus Project (http://www.perseus.tufts.edu), and and which (as far as I can tell) is licensed under Mozilla Public License 1.1 (MPL 1.1) (see http://www.mozilla.org/MPL/MPL-1.1.html)
 
 Because of its use of the above-mentioned morphology file, the verba-console app is licensed under the Mozilla Public License 1.1 (MPL 1.1) with the option to also license under the GPL. Note that Verba-Android does not use either of the above-mentioned Perseus project files, but rather depends on the output of a program which is licensed in a compatible way to the sources it uses.
